reasoning: The critique targets a substantive hinge in the essay’s trade-based optimism: the claim in §3.4 that preventing value-destroying threats makes outcomes much more optimistic. That’s meaningfully central to one of the essay’s main ‘paths to mostly-great futures,’ though not to the whole essay (which also argues against WAM-convergence and discusses other blockers), so centrality is moderate. The argument raises a real failure mode (harm displacement into covert/deniable channels under strong enforcement and categorisation problems), which would weaken the inference ‘threat prevention ⇒ higher EV’ unless observability/enforcement assumptions are specified. However, it’s largely a possibility argument and doesn’t establish that anti-threat regimes would generally worsen equilibria rather than improve them, so strength is limited-to-moderate. The claims are broadly plausible and conceptually sound but somewhat speculative and under-evidenced (e.g., that open threats are easier to counter-commit/insure against than covert harms), so correctness is decent but not near-1. It is clearly written, focused on a single issue, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Suppressing overt threats may displace coercion into harder-to-detect channels
